questions.question_text: A technician receives an alert indicating all VMs are down. After some troubleshooting, the technician discovers the network is out of space. To resolve the issue, the technician decides to add more space. Which of the following network types will the technician be working with?

discussion.content:
The technician will likely be working with a C. SAN (Storage Area Network).

A SAN is a dedicated high-speed network for storage devices. It provides block-level access to storage devices, allowing multiple servers to access shared storage. By adding more storage to the SAN, the technician can increase the available space for the virtual machines.

Here's why the other options are less relevant:

A. SCSI (Small Computer System Interface): SCSI is a type of storage interface, not a network type.
B. NAC (Network Access Control): NAC is a security solution that controls access to network resources. It's not directly related to storage expansion.
D. WISP (Wireless Internet Service Provider): A WISP provides wireless internet access. It's not relevant to storage expansion in a data center environment.
Therefore, a SAN is the most appropriate solution for increasing storage capacity in a virtualized environment.

GG

Selected Answer: C
A Storage Area Network (SAN) is the only option when we talk about adding more storage capacity.

questions.question_text: A cloud engineer, who is designing a cloud architecture, needs to ensure the solution is able to immediately fail over to another region in case of an outage and also scale up in the event of high utilization. Which of the following should the engineer implement? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Technically speaking Scale out is more VM's being provisioned for high demand. Scale UP is more CPU's and Memory etc being added - that is not elasticity since CPU is not hot swappable.

Selected Answer: AB
Answer: AB

A. High availability - High availability architecture is designed to minimize downtime by providing redundant systems and components. It ensures that if one region or data center experiences an outage, the workload can failover to another region with minimal interruption.

B. Elasticity - Elasticity is the ability to automatically scale resources up or down in response to changing demand. It allows the infrastructure to expand during periods of high utilization and contract when the demand decreases, which helps maintain performance and cost efficiency.

A is the right answer
RAID 0 is a configuration that stripes data across multiple disks without parity or redundancy. It provides the fastest speed and maximum storage capacity among the RAID types listed, but it also has no fault tolerance. RAID 1 mirrors data across two disks, providing redundancy but halving the storage capacity. RAID 5 stripes data across three or more disks with parity, providing fault tolerance but reducing the storage capacity by one disk. RAID 10 combines mirroring and striping across four or more disks, providing both speed and redundancy but reducing the storage capacity by half.

Selected Answer: A
Nobody mentioned redundancy. The other RAID implementations either require performance or space tradeoffs that compromise the intended objective.

comments.content: did you even read the question lmao

No mention of Redundancy in the Question.
Are you trying to trick or confuse us?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
If you need solid performance but also need a level of redundancy, RAID 10 is the best way to go. Keep in mind that you will lose half your usable storage, so plan accordingly! Redundancy: If redundancy is most important to you, you will be safe choosing either a RAID 10 or a RAID 60.

Selected Answer: A
RAID 0: High Performance
RAID 0 offers the fastest read/write speeds and maximum availability of raw storage capacity. Although RAID is typically associated with data redundancy, RAID 0 does not provide any. However, it does provide the best performance of any RAID level.

Selected Answer: A
A is actually correct because it provides maximum storage capacity

questions.question_text: A user wants RAID to be configured on a desktop to allow the fastest speed and maximum storage capacity. Which of the following RAID types should a technician configure to accommodate this request?

discussion.content: Duplex IS double-sided printing

C is the correct answer
Comprehensive and Detailed Step-by-Step Explanation: Modifying duplex settings to double-sided:
Printing on both sides of the paper (duplex printing) reduces paper usage, making it one of the most effective environmentally friendly printing initiatives.
It directly minimizes waste and supports sustainability goals in the workplace.

comments.content:
Incorrect Options:

A. Requiring user authentication for printing: While this can reduce unnecessary or unauthorized printing, it does not directly address environmental objectives like saving resources.

B. Locking down printing to only certain individuals: Limiting access may reduce printing overall, but it does not actively contribute to environmentally friendly practices like duplex printing.

D. Changing the print quality settings to best: Using the "best" print quality increases toner or ink usage, which is counterproductive to environmentally friendly objectives.
 
Reference: CompTIA A+ Core 1 Exam Objectives (220-1101), Domain 3.8 – Implementing best practices for environmental impact.
Plus if we use process of elimination on these question both A and B is similar because it is trying to limit people from printing, which is not "friendly" and D don't make sense for this question.

discussion.content:
I think its C. 
Which of the following printing initiatives would be BEST to accomplish environmentally friendly objectives? "environmentally friendly objectives"
Making every users to authenticate for ever print is not as friendly as just letting them print both side to save paper. 
C is the answer. we all overthinking this question.

Selected Answer: C
Options A and B focus more on user access control rather than addressing environmental concerns. Option D, changing the print quality settings to best, may increase the use of ink or toner without a significant environmental benefit. Option C is the only environmentally friendly answer.

Selected Answer: C
While A is a great way to eliminate wasteful printing you need to look at the overall. Usually most people grab their printouts from the printer than don't. Overall, setting to duplex so every print job prints on both sides would be more beneficial to the environmentally friendly objective. To further it that objective, you can then set A as your second choice.

I think its C to be honest. Because the question is talking about environmentally friendly objective. I think we are overthinking it with A. It should be C as it's the most simple and answers the question with no additional thinking needed. C directly answers the question as duplex printing reduces paper waste and benefits the environment.

Selected Answer: A
Should be A. People would limit printing if log exists.

Selected Answer: A
Sure duplxing will halve your paper requirements. But user authentication is the best known method to eliminate pointless printouts that are not needed in schools etc.

questions.question_text: Which of the following printing initiatives would be BEST to accomplish environmentally friendly objectives?

choices.B: Locking down printing to only certain individuals
choices.D: Changing the print quality settings to best

choices.A: Check the version of the HDMI cable.
choices.C: Set up the desktop for DVI.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
AB not BD because first we conduct research based on the symptoms BEFORE we test with a replacement cable. Otherwise, how do we know we're replacing with a known good cable without knowing what version is bad?

HDMI cables have different versions that support different features and bandwidths. For example, HDMI 1.4 supports up to 4K at 30 Hz, while HDMI 2.0 supports up to 4K at 60 Hz. The technician should check the version of the HDMI cable and make sure it matches the specifications of the monitor and the desktop. It sounds like the user is using HDMI 1.4 on a cutting edge monitor but you won't know until you check the cable version.

Selected Answer: AB
The first steps that the technician should perform are A. Check the version of the HDMI cable and B. Check the input source.
A possible cause of the problem is that the HDMI cable is not compatible with the 4K resolution of the monitor. HDMI cables have different versions that support different features and bandwidths. For example, HDMI 1.4 supports up to 4K at 30 Hz, while HDMI 2.0 supports up to 4K at 60 Hz1. The technician should check the version of the HDMI cable and make sure it matches the specifications of the monitor and the desktop.

comments.content: Another possible cause of the problem is that the monitor is not set to the correct input source. The input source is the option that allows the monitor to switch between different video signals from different ports, such as HDMI, DVI, VGA, or DisplayPort2. The technician should check the input source and make sure it is set to HDMI, since that is how the desktop is connected to the monitor. The input source can usually be changed using the buttons or menu on the monitor itself2.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
It cannot be the version of the HDMI cable because the question stated it was working previously.

Selected Answer: AB
A is for sure because older versions of HDMI don't support 4K resolutions, B for ensuring the input source
I think AB, because we are in the process to check.

Selected Answer: BD
The two FIRST steps the technician should perform are:

B. Check the input source:

Ensure that the monitor is set to the correct input source. If the monitor is expecting a signal from HDMI, make sure it is set to HDMI.
D. Replace the HDMI cable:

Faulty or incompatible HDMI cables can cause issues with signal transmission. Replace the HDMI cable with a known good cable to eliminate this potential problem.

comments.content: the monitor was working before however, so no need to check the HDMI.

discussion.content: I think there are AB because the question is the first step. So to you replace the cable HDMI, you need to first check whether the HDMI support 4k or not.. This makes more sense to me.

Selected Answer: BD
Definitely B and D

Selected Answer: BD
It’s B and D

questions.question_text: A user calls the help desk about a 4K monitor that will not output an image from a desktop. The monitor was working previously but now shows a black screen with a message stating a signal is not detected. The desktop is connected via HDMI, and the monitor has an empty DVI port. Which of the following steps should the technician perform FIRST? (Choose two.)
